head.title: The Elderly Are Ready to Click and Shop

hedline.hl1: The Elderly Are Ready to Click and Shop

abstract.p: Gert Cartino letter says online grocery shopping could be boon to the elderly (July 3 article)

block.p: The online grocery-shopping companies that are mentioned in your July 3 New Economy column, by Constance L. Hays, should take a look at a demographic group other than busy working families and 18- to 20-year-olds.
It occurs to me that the elderly would jump at the chance to order groceries through the Internet and have them delivered. I know I would, and I'm 78.

The online grocery-shopping companies that are mentioned in your July 3 New Economy column, by Constance L. Hays, should take a look at a demographic group other than busy working families and 18- to 20-year-olds.
It occurs to me that the elderly would jump at the chance to order groceries through the Internet and have them delivered. I know I would, and I'm 78.
I now pay someone to take me shopping for groceries. I would much rather do it with a click of the mouse, as I do other Internet shopping.
The elderly are heavy-duty computer users. The stories about our computer use are usually limited to our dalliance with e-mail to our families, but we do in fact live beyond that.
I think the online grocery startups should rethink their service areas and concentrate on us.
GERT CARTINO Fort Lauderdale, Fla., July 3, 2000
